ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of current issues in international law and human rights
Understanding of the nuance of international law

Before this course, I had no experience in International law or human rights material. However, this class was extremely well facilitated so that I was able to meaningfully engage with the texts, discussion, and assignments. I now have a much more solid understanding of sovereignty and socioeconomic rights as applied to international law, and it has inspired me to think about the world order in quite a new light.

better understanding of international law framework and its different instrument. Learned about how international law relates to several aspects of society, like sea, space, social rights, econ rights, human rights, environment, urbanism, etc.

Understanding a *lot* better the international legal system and theory behind it, as well as pressing issues in which international legal scholarship is being applied. How to perform research about these topics and write about them. How to read legal scholarship.

This class gave me an in-depth understanding of the legal processes underlying international law. The course covered a wide range of specific topics that each came with their own complexities and nuances. I learned that what might seem very simple from a moral perspective was indeed very complicated from a geopolitical or legal standpoint.
How to understand the complexities of international law.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: excellent in-class discussions with people expressing different viewpoints on nuanced topics
Weaknesses: some of the readings felt a little random, especially towards the end of the course
Even though previous knowledge was not required for the class, I struggled a little bit because I felt I was not as knowledgable as some of my classmates going in.

Strengths: interesting texts, and interesting class discussions. Also, the final allowed students to choose their own topic, which was a great way for us to pick something we were interested in and take a deep dive into it.
great enthusiastic professor. reading didnt really connect to class discussions.
This course is very well organized with strong thematic approaches to readings, very topical discussions, and very engaging and complex conversations in class.
The readings were fascinating and varied. I thought that discussion was very strong. Professor Omri did an amazing job of making the classroom feel supportive and inclusive.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! Especially those who have a prior interest in international human rights and international law. Naama does a good job of providing background readings on the various legal mechanisms and treaties that exist, but it helps to have familiarity with socio-economic rights issues
Yes, if you are very interested in the subject you will really enjoy. If not, its a lot of reading and discussion that you would not enjoy.
Yes, especially if you have any interest in any of the main elements of sovereignty, socioeconomic rights, or international law.
yes! if youre interested in international law.
Absolutely!

Definitely take this course if you are interested in any of these topics or in law in general. A good overview of legal theory, and lots of context-based applications discussions. The readings are particularly strong, topical, and very engaging if you spend time with them.
Yes! If you are interested in international relations or human rights, this is the perfect class for you.
If interested in pursuing international law, yes!
